thread.title: Lady Tigers handle River Valley

title: Lady Tigers handle River Valley
text: Lady Tigers handle River Valley JC AMBERLYN/Miner Academy freshman Isabella Anderson lets rip a serve during the Lady Tigers win over River Valley at KAHS Thursday. Shawn Byrne Miner Staff Reporter KINGMAN - One sign of a maturing team is how it handles the supposed-to-win matches. The Kingman Academy High volleyball squad exhibited that sign in the Lady Tigers Division IV, Section III win over River Valley Thursday at KAHS - 25-17, 26-24, 25-27, 25-15."We've started to come together," said KAHS volleyball coach Ken David. "We can't look forward or look past anyone. We have to focus on every single point."Breezy Weber led the Academy (5-8, 1-1) with 16 digs and 12 kills."We worked so well as a team," the sophomore middle hitter said. "We had mistakes, and that was the only thing that brought us down. Once we got over them, we worked as a team and it was perfect."Sophomore setter Shaunti Short had 25 assists and added four kills. Senior Ashteyn Whirlow served up five aces.The Lady Tigers' core group is made up of freshmen and sophomores, and they continue to experience hiccups, such as Game 3 when the Academy let a 19-11 lead disappear. River Valley (5-10, 1-1) rallied to win the game."It was all just our mistakes," Weber said. "It was everything on our side of the net. We fixed it for the last game, so that was good."Another impressive manifestation from the Lady Tigers is their performance without sophomore hitter Aspen Jackson, who didn't play as she continued to nurse a sprained ankle. Jackson, despite missing the last three matches, leads the Academy with 69 kills. "She's definitely our MVP," Weber said.At no point during the River Valley match did the Lady Tigers appear to miss Jackson."We've adjusted pretty quickly," David said. "I have to give credit to the team with next lady up."Jackson said she was ready to return to practice, which she did on Friday. David said she felt good and trusted it more and that he expects her to be back at full speed this week.Academy faces Cortez (1-10, 0-2) Tuesday in Phoenix. Lady Vols swept again Lee Williams (7-7 Division III, 1-2 Section II) was swept for the second consecutive match Thursday. This time it was No. 29 Shadow Ridge (9-4, 2-1) in a 25-10, 25-20, 25-22 win.Sadie Snay's five kills and eight assists led the Lady Vols. Khori Cobanovich came up with 14 digs, and freshman Chania Scott recorded four blocks and Holly McFadyen added three.Lee Williams hosts Kingman (0-12, 0-3) at 6 p.m. Tuesday. The Lady Vols are in 46th place in D-III. The top 32 teams will advance to the postseason. Lee Williams has four matches remaining and it appears it must win all four to have any chance, including the Oct. 27 game against No. 2 Parker. Parker slides by Kingman Parker (14-0, 4-0) cruised past Kingman (0-12, 0-3) Thursday at KHS 25-7, 25-14, 25-8. Catherine Angle led the Lady Bulldogs with 11 digs, and Anyssa Fuhrmeister had five assists.KHS plays at Lee Williams Tuesday.
